results.notes:
The key to the 51 Fragilipedes in Robich’s 2nd volume of “Mycena d’Europa” leads to Mycena subcana without much doubt. It came as a surprise: subcana typically has a relatively short stipe and in all pictures I’ve seen has nearly perfectly symmetric caps. Smiths says, however, that growth among dense moss can produce longer stems.

Spores ~8-8.5 × 4-5, sometimes almost cylindrical. (NB: M. abramsii has spores 9-13 microns long.)

A single mushroom, growing on oak leaf. It’s immature, there were no spores or basidia with visible sterigmata, and the cheilocystidia were mostly smooth; those that weren’t had the rounded excrescences, as they should.

Canthrellus cibarius Fr., Cantharellaceae, Aphyllophorales. (Chanterelle или Лисичка обыкновенная).
Cap: 2-8cm, gently convex up to flat with in rolled wavy margin, old one often sunken; color is bright yellow or orange-yellow up to dull yellow. Cap surface is smooth and sometimes some wavy; flesh is thick and yellowish-white. Gills are attached and descending stalk, narrow and thick-edged; forked and rare cross-veined; color from yellow up to dull yellow.
Stalk: 2-6cm long, usually enlarged up to a cap; light yellow up to yellow; 0.5-2cm thick. Edibility: good and tasty.
Habitat: small group minor big clusters scattered in pine-tree forest; sometimes under birches in the same forest.
Season: June – August.

Tricholoma album (Schaeff.) P. Kumm., Tricholomataceae, Agaricales. (Рядовка белая)
Whitish mushroom with a convex smooth cap and close gills
Cap: 5-12cm wide (up to 16cm in rainy warm season), white or yellowish-white, smooth, convex up to broadly convex, sticky in wet weather; margin curved in when young, later it curved upper or horizontal and a cap looks as a big wide knob. Flesh is white; odor is unpleasant and somewhat soapy.
Gills: attached with narrowing toward stalk, close, narrow up to moderately broad when old, white up to cream-white (There are often young white mushrooms with rare gills and unpleasant odor inside Tricholoma album clusters, the similar data are for Tricholoma saponaceum, but different colors of caps).
Stalk: 5-12cm long, 1.5-2.5cm thick and enlarged toward base, white or whitish, somewhat cottony when young.
Habitat: common kind in rainy summer, small or big groups, minor single scattered in pine-tree forest with some birches (sometimes nearby birch stumps).
Edibility: published that poisonous.
Season: July-August.

results.notes:
Amanita muscaria group, Amanitaceae, Agaricales.
(Мухомор оранжево-красный, мухомор красный).

Cap: 8-16cm wide (when adult), convex up to flattened, sometimes slightly sunken; color is red-orange up to irregular dull orange-yellow (age discoloring); old margins becoming radial lined and orange-yellow; white patches usually concentrically arranged and pyramidal when young (some patches disappeared after rains when old). Cap surface is smooth and some tacky in wet weather; young cap has remains of cotton.
Gills: free or slightly attached, close, moderately broad; color from white up to weak yellowish-white when old.
Stalk: 8-18cm long, white up to dull cream; 1.5-3cm thick, slightly enlarging down with rounded basal bulb with rows of cottony patches as rims; stalk sometimes hollow with edging.
Partial veil is white and collapsing, leaving pendant ring at upper part of stalk. Spore print is white. Edibility: poisonous.
Habitat: single or small groups scattered in pine-tree forest with rare birches.
July – September.

results.notes:
Suillus variegatus (Sw.) Kuntze. Boletaceae, Agaricales. (Моховик желто-бурый)
Cap: 5-16cm wide, convex up to wide convex; smooth or fine velvety when dry time; dull orange-brown or yellowish-brown up to brownish-yellow or dirty orange-yellow and micro-spotty with darker 0.5-3mm spots and also as micro depressions. The skin is not separated. Flesh is yellowish-white up to light yellow (gray after boiling).
Tubes: attached, sometimes slightly descending, colour irregular from ochre-yellow and greenish-yellow (with tiny reddish holes) up to greenish-orange-brown for very old unit; bruising is reddish for young and greenish-blue for old ones.
Stalk: 4-8cm long, light yellow and orange-yellow with reddish coloring above and weak greenish-blue colouring after cutting; 1.2-3cm thick, young stalk has classic King Bolete shape (most narrow at the top and gradually enlarged down), old one sometimes is knob-shaped at the base.
Habitat: common kind, scattered small groups, sometimes abundant in pine-tree forest somewhere with rare birches. It is also abundant in all Russian mushroom sites.
Edibility: good, it looks after boiling as Leccinum scabrum with the similar taste.
July – August.

results.notes: In the field MO 249154, 249812 and 249813 appeared to me to be the same taxon. When first collected I thought they seemed to match the macro description of A. nishidae at http://www.amanitaceae.org/?Amanita nishidae but upon review I think there are several key differences. Young caps of A. nishidae are described as being “fulvous or browner with olivaceous tint” and the photos at the Amanita site show young specimens with a browner disc. This cap of these obs lacks brown and olivaceous tones. And from the Amanita site : “Volval remnants on the cap are commonly absent.” and “They are present occasionally as a small, soft, easily removed, membranous, white patch in the center of the cap…” The volval patch on these obs is rather large, persistent and not easily removed except in the case of the old faded specimen. The gills on these obs appear fimbriate and are orange cream in color. And these obs were in association with ponderosa pine and gambel oak, in the case of 249154 pure ponderosa pine, at about 7300-7500’ elevation. I’m not sure about the habitat for A. nishidae though I know it was montane in the case of the southern Az collections and likely included one or more varieties of pine.

results.notes:
Amanita muscaria var. guessowii Veselý, Amanitaceae, Agaricales. (Мухомор оранжево-желтый).
Cap: 6-12cm wide (when adult), convex up to flattened, sometimes slightly sunken; colour is yellow-orange up to irregular dull orange-yellow; old margins becoming radial lined and orange-yellow; white patches usually concentrically arranged and pyramidal when young (some patches disappears after rains when old). Cap surface is smooth and some tacky in wet weather; young cap has remains of cotton.
Gills: free or slightly attached, close, moderately broad; colour from white up to weak yellowish-white when old.
Stalk: 8-16cm long, white up to yellowish-white; 1.5-3cm thick, enlarging down with rounded basal bulb and often with rows of cottony patches as rims; stalk usually hollow with edging.
Partial veil is white and collapsing, leaving pendant ring at upper part of stalk. Spore print is white.
Edibility: poisonous.
Habitat: single or small groups scattered in pine-tree forest with rare birches.
July – August.

Fongarium: cKc0001
Date: 11.VI.2016
Biotopes: pousse au sol tout près de bois pourri et moussu de feuillus ;

Macromorphologie
Chapeau brun à brun foncé vers le centre à la marge nettement plus pâle dans les teintes de crème 40-70 mm Ø ;
Lames libres, rosées ;
Pied méchuleux 50-80 × 7-11 mm Ø ;

Articles:
- Justo, Alfredo et al. Molecular phylogeny and phylogeography of Holarctic species of Pluteus section Pluteus (Agaricales: Pluteaceae), with description of twelve new species, Phytotaxa 180 (1): 001-085, (2014) 85 p.; doi.org/10.11646/phytotaxa.180.1.1 ;

Micro
Planche micrographique: cKc0001-0129
Collection étudiée sur matériel déshydraté ;

Micro
Basides longuement claviformes à subfusiformes ou comme une petite massue dont l’apex est subtronqué, 2-4 stérigmates, non bouclées à la base, à contenu vacuolaire ou bien carminophile, émergentes sur la moitié de leur longueur lorsque mature (27,7) 32,4 – 38 (38,9) × (7,3) 7,4 – 8,8 (9,1) µm en moyenne ;
Spores ovoïdes à subtriangulaires vue frontale, elliptiques à largement elliptiques vue de profil, lisses, à paroi mince à légèrement épaissie, petit appendice hilaire, à contenu parfois uniguttulé à granulations, hyalines dans l’eau glycérinée 20 %, inactives dans le melzer, non cyanophiles
(6,1) 6,3 – 7,8 (8) × (4,5) 4,7 – 5,2 (6,1) µm
Q = (1,2) 1,3 – 1,5 (1,6) ; N = 30
Me = 6,8 × 4,9 µm ; Qe = 1,4
(Piximètre: formule classique) ;
Cheilocystides abondantes, polymorphes, formant une bande bien développée, piriformes à largement piriformes (22,6) 26,5 – 47,8 (56,6) × (11,9) 12,4 – 18,5 (20,3) µm en moyenne, ellipsoïdes-ovoïdes à largement ellipsoïdes-ovoïdes, sphéropédonculées, 43,6 – 61,8 × 19,6 – 28,2 µm en moyenne, hyalines à paroi mince ;
Cheilocystides intermédiaires rares, fusiformes dont l’apex est sans crochets et dont la paroi est sensiblement épaissie 41,8 – 44,3 × 11,2 – 12,2 µm en moyenne, à fusiformes ventrues dont l’apex est rostré 50-55 × 17-20 µm en moyenne ;
Lampropleurocystides nombreuses, métuloïdes, fusiformes (76,9) 77,5 – 85,9 (95,7) × (11,4) 13,5 – 17,6 (20,3) µm en moyenne, souvent avec 3-4 (5) crochets apicaux bien développés dont la plupart sont entiers, quelques bifides, à paroi jusqu’à 2,5 µm d’épaisseur ;
Caulopellis en cutis ;
Caulocystides absentes, plutôt des hyphes terminales éparses ;
Pileipellis en cutis (ixocutis) formé d’éléments cylindriques emmêlées, lisses, à paroi mince, hyalines ou remplis de pigment intracellulaire brun, avec extrémités subfusiformes à claviformes (38,3) 41 – 70,1 (80) × (6) 8,5 – 13,5 (16,7) µm en moyenne, avec matrice gélatinée présente chez certaines collections ;
Remarque: Les crochets apicaux sont proéminents et mesures en moyenne entre 4-5 (8) µm de longueur ;

Articles:
- Justo, Alfredo et al. Molecular phylogeny and phylogeography of Holarctic species of Pluteus section Pluteus (Agaricales: Pluteaceae), with description of twelve new species, Phytotaxa 180 (1): 001-085, (2014) 85 p.; doi.org/10.11646/phytotaxa.180.1.1 ;

Fongarium: cKc0500
Date: 23.VI.2016
Biotopes: pousse sur bois pourri de feuillus (hêtre à grandes feuilles) ;

Macromorphologie
Chapeau étalé, omboné, légèrement déprimé, viscidule, brun-gris à olivâtre foncé à noirâtre vers le centre, 84 mm Ø ;
Lames libres, gris-beige devenant légèrement rosâtres à maturité ;
Pied cylindrique arqué, fibrilles longitudinales brunes à brun-gris pâle, squamuleux vers la base, bulbeux, 58 × 7 mm Ø ;
Odeur fongique à légèrement raphanoïde ;
Saveur fongique avec une finale amère ;

Micro
Planche micrographique: cKc0500-0133
Collection étudiée sur matériel déshydraté ;

Basides claviformes à subfusiformes ou comme une petite massue dont l’apex est subtronqué, 2-4 stérigmates, non bouclées à la base, à contenu vacuolaire ou bien carminophile, (25,1 – 35,2 × 7,1 – 8,5 µm en moyenne ;
Basidiospores ovoïdes à subtriangulaires vue frontale, elliptiques à largement elliptiques vue de profil, ou légèrement resserré au milieu, lisses, à paroi mince à légèrement épaissie, petit appendice hilaire, à contenu uniguttulé à granulations, hyalines dans l’eau glycérinée 20 %, inactives dans le melzer, non cyanophiles
(6,4) 6,7 – 7,7 (7,9) × (4,5) 4,7 – 5,4 (5,5) µm
Q = (1,3) 1,34 – 1,6 (1,7) ; N = 30
Me = 7,2 × 5 µm ; Qe = 1,5
(Piximètre: formule classique ; basidiospores mesurées dans l’eau glycérinée 20 %) ;
Cheilocystides nombreuses, polymorphes, claviformes, piriformes à subpiriformes 37,7 – 59,3 × 15,7 – 18,9 µm en moyenne, subglobuleuses 20,7 – 27 × 20,2 – 20,3 µm en moyenne, sphéropédonculées 39,5 – 56,5 × 15,4 – 20,8 µm en moyenne ;
Cheilocystides intermédiaires occasionnelles (plus nombreuses à l’arête lamellaire) plus petites et moins bien développées que les lampropleurocystides, fusiformes à cylindriques, souvent avec crochets difformes ou avec un seul crochet, 52,7 – 59,6 × 10,7 – 15,9 µm en moyenne ;
Lampropleurocystides abondantes, métuloïdes, fusiformes (70,4) 72,3 – 84,1 (89,6) × 16,5 – 23,7 µm en moyenne, souvent avec 3-4 (5) crochets apicaux bien développés dont la moitié sont entiers, et l’autre moitié sont bifides, à paroi jusqu’à 2,5 (2,7 µm) µm d’épaisseur ;
Pileipellis en cutis formé d’éléments cylindriques emmêlées, lisses, à paroi mince, hyalines ou remplis de pigment intracellulaire brun, avec extrémités subfusiformes à claviformes (38,3) 41 – 70,1 (80) × (6) 8,5 – 13,5 (16,7) µm en moyenne ;
Boucles absentes du pileipellis et non observées dans aucune autre partie du basidiome ;
Remarque: Sur 60 sommets apicaux de lampropleurocystides, nous obtenons exactement 30 sommets avec crochets entiers, et 30 sommets avec crochets bifides ;

Macromorphologie
Apothécie sphérique à arrondie puis discoïdes, sessile, 3-8 mm Ø ;
Hyménophore lisse, orangé ;
Face externe couverte modérément de poils bruns noirs, bordant la marge comme des cils ;
Chair fragile ;

Micro
Planche micrographique: cKc0515-0136
Collection étudiée sur matériel frais ;

Micro
Asques cylindriques octosporées, à apex arrondi, IKI -, non operculé, dont la base est acrorhynque ;
Paraphyses nombreuses, simples, septées, dichotomiquement ramifiées, de deux types: 1) cylindriques, dont l’apex est claviforme jusqu’à 7 µm de largeur, avec contenu pailleté jaune or dans l’eau devenant rosâtre dans le Soudan, 200 – 207 × 6,3 – 7,1) µm en moyenne ; 2) cylindriques, dont l’apex forme une truelle (utriformes) jusqu’à 30-38 × 8-8,8 (9) µm de largeur ;
Ascospores unisériées, ellipsoïdes, formées des verrues interconnectées et de courtes crêtes, à contenu pluriguttulé, non coloration des inclusions lipidiques (guttules) au Soudan III
(15,7) 17,7 – 19,3 (21,1) × (10,2) 10,4 – 11,5 (12,1) µm

Me = 18,6 × 10,9 µm ; Qe = 1,7
(Piximètre: formule classique, issues d’une sporée et mesures dans le bleu Coton lactique) ;
Remarque: Non réactif au Soudan III ;
Poils atténués à l’apex, à la base bifide, à paroi épaissie, avec plusieurs septa fins, brun très foncé 434,6 × 849,8 µm en moyenne ;

Cap: 6-12cm wide, pale yellowish-brown or light brownish-gray up to brownish-gray (irregular coloured pink-gray and pinkish-brown when very old) smooth and shining, convex or “square head” (young) up to broadly convex sometimes with indistinct wide knob or depression and irregular wavy margins, often with radial cracks; often overlapped, sometimes inter grow each other. Gills: attached with pinching out toward stalk (narrow and slightly descending when very young), moderately broad up to broad, whitish or yellowish-white when old.
Stalk: 6-10cm long, 1.0-2.5cm thick and usually enlarged toward base, white and silky up to brownish-white and indistinct fibrous. They accreted together by two or by three, minor more.

Edibility: good.
Season: July-August.

results.notes: Growing adjacent to Red Maple in forest. Colors seemed darker than photos — cap top cocoa brown, stem had slight purplish cast. About 3 cm dia.

Although the cap shows more yellow than red, I wonder if these may be a faded version of A. jacksonii. Jacksonii occurs in this area, and there are currently a few of them fairly beat up by rainfall that have changed from predominantly red to reddish on the disc with yellow margin. But this one is in pretty good shape, and the cap is quite pale. And the ornamentation on the stipe is paler and distributed in smaller scales/ patches than what I’d expect for jacksonii.

Spores are longer than what is reported for jacksonii, 8.5-11.5 × 6-7.5. (Actually, I see much different jacksonii spore dimensions reported on ASW and Mushroom Expert; maybe due to confusion with other red/orange/yellow American Caesars?)

Cap vivid purplish red, diameter around 7 inches, margin wavy/firm.

Pores yellow bruising grayish-blue, and in some areas brownish.

Stipe about 2.5 inches diameter, yellow with wide/coarse reddish-brown reticulatum becoming a reddish-brown coating on the lower half. Base with yellow mycelium dotted red.

Context whitish in cap, yellow in stipe with yellow areas, stained red near worm holes. All context staining slowly and fairly faintly blue when cut.

Ammonia: green flash becoming orange on cap, pale lemon yellow on context.

KOH: vivid orange on cap surface, yellowish-orange on cap context, muddy orange on stipe context.

Undamaged portion sliced and dehydrated.

A magnificent sight from 80 feet away.

I returned to this spot 4 days later, after a heavy rainfall, and there were three additional (smaller) specimens in the same 50 square yard area.

results.notes:
Single specimen, growing on oak acorn cup. Cap 5-6 mm, stem ~3cm.

Spores 9-12 × 4-5, elongated (Q about 3). Basidia 4-spored, (25-35) + (3-5) x (7-8). Cheilocystidia 30-40 × 7-12, bilaterally symmetric (no extra necks or excrescences). No pleurocystidia observed.

All the above characters and the macro features seen in the photos match the description of M. roseoquercina. The only exception is prominent lanceolate caulocystidia; in the published description they are irregular and lavishly diverticulate.

The authors say that “the combination of very small size, narrow spores and special habitat is discriminative for M. roseoquercina”.

I was not disappointed.

results.notes:
Lyophyllum decastes (Fr.) Singer, Tricholomataceae, Agaricales. (Fried-chicken Mushroom, лиофиллум скученный, рядовка скученная).
Cap: 6-12cm wide, pale yellowish-brown or light brownish-gray up to brownish-gray, often radial streaked or irregular coloured, smooth, convex or “square head” (young) up to broadly convex sometimes with indistinct wide knob or depression and irregular wavy margins, sometimes with radial cracks; often overlapped, sometimes inter grow each other. Flesh is white; odour is pleasant.
Gills: attached with pinching out toward stalk (narrow and slightly descending when very young), moderately broad up to broad, whitish or yellowish-white when old.
Stalk: 6-10cm long, 1.0-2.5cm thick and usually enlarged toward base, white and silky when young up to brownish-white and indistinct fibrous. They accreted together by two or by three, minor more.
Habitat: small crowded clusters in pine-tree forest with some birches.
Edibility: good.
Season: July-August.

Mushroom: 3-6cm wide, 6-12 cm high, often pear-shaped with elongated base as a false cylindrical stalk (sometimes stalk enlarged toward a base), turban-shaped top is covered with tiny short spines, they become smaller toward down as coarse powder; white up to whitish then ochre-brown or olive-brown with aging; cap and stalk compose a single white body with white flesh when young, then greenish-yellow up to olive-brown spore powder as dry dust. Sometimes a cap splits with a crack from a stalk before maturing. Old cap is easily broken off or blows up with spore powder; mushroom turns into residual ochre-brown stalk with some loose remnants of pore-bearing sag.

Edibility: edible and tasty when young and flesh is white.

These were found on a neighbor’s lawn in between several mature oaks, a hemlock, and a maple. It is a myco-rich area where I have found at least 5-10 different bolete species and at least 20 others. The last photo shows a mushroom found nearby that I would call “classic subvelutipes.” These differ from that one in so many material ways that they are clearly not the same species. I was here 5 days earlier so the mushrooms cannot be older than that.

There has been a good bit of recent rain but the ground is still dry, if no longer baked.

Mycelium was white. Cap was very dark brown. More mature specimens were flat on top with rounded pores, while younger specimens were flat underneath with a rounded cap. The pores on all were dry to the touch and the context was a little marshmallow-y, but very few of the mushrooms were desiccated or elderly enough to significantly change their characteristics. It should be clear from the photos. There is a strong mushroom smell that the owner says is typical (he dislikes mowing over them because of it!).

The pore color was, quite frankly, odd. At first I thought it was a red-mouth with yellow edges that had dried into the dark brown range. But the specimens were constantly that color despite their age, with only a slightly darker shade for the ones that were well and truly old. I cannot say that the pore color in these photos is unusually dark for the species. At the same time, it has a very different look-and-feel from the vermiculosoides I have found in the area.

The most striking feature is the staining of the context. The underlying, pre-stained context is creamy yellow (the photos seem whiter than they look in life). When cut the stipe very rapidly stained a bright red, while the cap slowly and indifferently stained toward blue. This was consistent in every one of the half-dozen specimens I tested, and I was able to confirm that the red was a change in color after slicing rather than a preexisting shade. As shown in one of the photos, the red in the stipe persisted even four hours later (though chemical tests turned it brown). I also noted that when mushrooms were snapped off a ground level, there was a brilliant red spot visible in the bottom inside of the stipe. (Bad photo, but that is what it is showing.)

Chemical tests were all indifferent and hard to read.

SUPPLEMENTAL NOTES The specimens dried out “puffy” and with an unusually powerful mushroom smell. This is consistent with a comment from the neighbor who owns the property where they were found: “I call this the ‘stinky mushrooms’ because they reek like crazy when you run them over with the lawnmower.”

Fongarium : cKc0420
Date : 19.VIII.2015
Biotopes : pousse au sol, sur pelouse, sous frêne ;
Cueilli sous les frênes ; probablement en symbiose avec le puceron (ou aphide) Melia Rhizophagus fraxinifolia; pousse dispersés ou grégaire; été et l’automne ; largement distribué dans l’est de l’Amérique du Nord (poussant peut-être aussi dans le sud-ouest) ;

Chapeau 50-200 mm Ø, convexe quand il est jeune, puis étalé à concave à maturité, sec à viscidule, glabre ou presque, brun rougeâtre, brun jaunâtre ou brun olivâtre, à marge incurvée puis souvent ondulée ou gondolent, avec bande étroite de tissu stérile ;
Face poroïde jaune à jaune olivacé, immuable ou devenant lentement bleu-vert au froissement ;
Pores anguleux et interveinés, bolétinoïdes, parfois sublamellés, très larges, 1 mm ou plus de largeur ;
Couche(s) de tubes décurrente, concolore à la face poroïde, 3-6 mm de longueur ;
Pied 20-45 × 5-25 mm Ø, souvent excentré à latéral, court, subégal, souvent courbe, plein, jaune vers l’apex, brun vers la base, arrivant de nombreux sclérotes ;
Chair blanchâtre à jaunâtre, immuable ou devenant lentement bleu-vert à la coupe, surtout au-dessus de la couche de tubes ;
Odeur et saveur odeur et saveur indistinctes ;
Sporée brun olivacé ;
Réactions chimiques noirâtre puis rouge terne à orangé au KOH ou NH4OH sur le chapeau ;

Micro
Planche micrographique: cKc0420-0114

Micro
Basides piriformes, claviformes à largement claviformes, tétrastérigmates, bouclées à la base, hyalines dans le NaCl, à contenu vacuolaires, (30,6) 30,7 – 36,7 (37,6) × (8,3) 9 – 12,8 (13,5) µm ;
Spores elliptiques vue de face, largement elliptiques à elliptiques vue de profil, lisses, à paroi mince à légèrement épaissie 0,2-0,3 µm, avec petit appendice hilaire, pore germinatif légèrement excentré à excentré et bien visible dans le melzer 1,7-2 µm, à contenu uniguttulé, hyalines dans le NaCl iso, dextrinoïdes, non cyanophiles
(7,5) 7,9 – 8,6 (9,5) × (5,4) 5,6 – 6,2 (6,9) µm
Q = (1,3) 1,32 – 1,4 (1,5) ; N = 30
Me = 8,2 × 6 µm ; Qe = 1,4
(Piximètre: formule classique)
Cheilocystides non observées ;
Pleurocystides rare et non émergentes, cylindriques ;
Pileipellis en cutis avec des hyphes pigmentées, emmêlées et émergentes 3-10 µm de largeur ;
Trame tubulaire parallèle à subparallèle ;
Boucles observées dans le pileipellis ;

Fongarium: cKc0512
Date: 04.07.2016
Biotopes: pousse sur sol sablonneux, dans la mousse ;

Macromorphologie
Apothécie 6-13 (15) mm Ø, discoïdes à légèrement cupuliformes entre 4-7 mm de profondeur, hygrophane, beige imbu, beige pâle opaque au sec, non épigé ;
Hyménophore lisse, brun pâle à verdâtre ;
Face externe sublisse à finement granuleuse, brun beige pâle ;
Pied absent ;
Chair mince, fragile, cassante ;
Odeur indistincte ;
Saveur indistincte à légèrement fongique ;
Sporée blanchâtre ;
Latex jaune ;
Remarque: Non épigé, car l’apothécie ne dépasse jamais la surface du sol, vraiment au ras du sol ; Voir aussi la collection cKc0505 ;

Micro
Planche micrographique: cKc0512-0134
Collection étudiée sur matériel frais ;
Asques claviformes dont l’apex est tronqué, octosporés, à apex IKI +b, operculé, avec base de type acrorhynque, 255,5 – 264,5 × 12,4 – 13,4 µm en moyenne ;
Paraphyses simples, cylindriques-filiformes, hyalines dans l’eau, à contenu brun rouille sur toute la longueur dans le Lugol, dont parfois le contenu est discontinu et forme des plaques (gouttelettes) éparses, septées, à apex parfois égal à subégal, arrondis, rarement subcapité, + 180 – 245 × 4,5 – 6,3 µm en moyenne ;
Ascospores unisériées, ellipsoïdes, grossièrement verruqueuses jusqu’à 1 µm de hauteur, avec réticulum irrégulier de rides trapues, à contenu biguttulé jeune, par la suite uniguttulé (coloration en bleu verdâtre foncé des inclusions lipidiques (guttules) au Soudan III ou noir Soudan B)
(14,5) 14,7 – 17,3 (17,7) × (7,8) 8,3 – 9 (9,1) µm
Q = (1,6) 1,7 – 2 (2,1) ; N = 30
Me = 16 × 8,6 µm ; Qe = 1,9
(Piximètre: formule classique, issues d’une sporée et mesures dans le bleu Coton lactique, sans les ornements) ;
Excipulum médullaire supérieur de textura globulosa-angularis ;
Poils hyphoïdes du réceptacle ;
Remarques: Le Soudan III ou noir Soudan B permet de colorer les inclusions lipidiques (guttules) trouvées fréquemment dans les ascospores. Le soudan III est soluble dans des solvants de type white spirit, mais n’est pas facilement miscible à l’eau ; son utilisation en mycologie/lichénologie pose donc des problèmes, l’eau étant le principal constituant des êtres vivants. On peut utiliser le soudan III en solution alcoolique saturée mais l’éthanol provoque un rétrécissement important des structures cellulaires. » (Jean-Pierre Gaveriaux) (informations tirées des fiches de Marcel Lecomte) ; La taille des ascospores et le type de guttules (généralement une grande guttule) suggèrent P. succosella (dixit R. Dougoud) ;

Clé:
- Hohmeyer, H. Une clé pour les espèces d’Europe du genre Peziza L., extraite de Zeitschrift für Mykologie, Band. 52 (1): 1-248, April 1986, traduction par P. A. Renaud en collaboration avec R. Dougoud, Fribourg, 1988.

Biotopes: pousse au sol sous feuillus, bouleaux, chênes et hêtres à grandes feuilles ;

Macromorphologie
Chapeau globuleux à convexe, puis étalé, visqueux au début, lisse, jaune ocré pâle, jaune-brun, à marge striée-tuberculée et cuticule pelant jusqu’au ¾ du rayon, 40-100 mm Ø ;
Lames adnées, larges, subespacées à serrées, crème ja grisâtres, souvent tachées de brun pâle ocré ;
Pied égal, ferme, lisse, blanchâtre à blanc jaunâtre, se tachant parfois de brun jaunâtre, 30-100 × 10-30 mm Ø ;
Chair blanche ;
Odeur prononcé d’amende, ou de massepain (benzaldéhyde) ;
Saveur douce, avec une finale aigrelette ;
Sporée crème ocré IIc-IId d’après la charte de couleur de Sarnari/Romagnesi & C-D d’après la charte de couleur de Kibby ;

Micro
Planche micrographique : cKc0108-0069
Basides largement fusiformes à elliptiques-ovoïdes, plus rarement subutriformes, tétrastérigmates, non bouclées à la base, 26,7 [36,5; 63,6] 73,5 × 9 [11,4; 18] 20,4 µm en moyenne
Spores globuleuses à subglobuleuses, majoritairement verruqueuses, munies de hautes crêtes ailées et partiellement réticulées, avec proéminences allant de 1,6-2,4 µm de hauteur, à paroi mince, avec appendice hilaire, plage hilaire subamyloïde pas toujours bien visible, à contenu uniguttulé dans le NaCl iso, hyalines dans le NaCl iso, amyloïdes
8 [8,7; 9] 9,7 × 7,5 [8,3; 8,7] 9,5 µm
Q = [1; 1,05] 1,1; N = 25; C = 95%
Me = 8,8 × 8,5 µm; Qe = 1
Pleurocystides nombreuses, fragiles, cylindriques avec apex moniliformes, à cylindriques avec étranglement et se terminant souvent mucronées;
Piléocystides peu nombreuses, cylindriques, Sulfopipéronal positif (SP+);
Pileipellis en deux strates : un cutis surmonté d’une partie gélatineuse en ixocutis;
poils septés;

The type species of Melanotus is M. bambusinus, described from Vietnam in 1896, but only spore characters are known from two collections said to be in “fragmentary condition” by Horak1. In Agaricales in Modern Taxonomy 4th Ed., Singer lists, seven other species known to occur on herbaceous substrates, some of which have a Neotropical distribution, but none (that I have found so far) make any mention of any orange in the stipe.

Cap: 3-8cm, gently convex up to flat with in rolled wavy margin, old one sometimes sunken; color is bright yellow or orange-yellow up to dull yellow. Cap surface is smooth and sometimes some wavy; flesh is thick and yellowish-white.
Gills: attached and descending stalk, narrow and thick-edged; forked and rare cross-veined, usually with lots of additional transversal gills when old; color from yellow up to dull yellow.
Stalk: 3-6cm long, usually enlarged up to a cap; light yellow up to yellow; 0.5-2cm thick.
Edibility: good and tasty.
Habitat: small group minor big clusters scattered in soil with pine needles minor in moss in pine-tree forest with rare birches.
Season: June – August.

Sticky cap that is pale orangish brown over disc with lined margin, no ring, white volval sac that is orange on the interior, with ponderosa pine and gambel oak, older faded out specimen fresh one nearby see obs 249813.

PS In the field MO 249154, 249812 and 249813 appeared to me to be the same taxon. When first collected I thought they seemed to match the macro description of A. nishidae at http://www.amanitaceae.org/?Amanita nishidae but upon review I think there are several key differences. Young caps of A. nishidae are described as being “fulvous or browner with olivaceous tint” and the photos at the Amanita site show young specimens with a browner disc. This cap of these obs lacks brown and olivaceous tones. And from the Amanita site : “Volval remnants on the cap are commonly absent.” and “They are present occasionally as a small, soft, easily removed, membranous, white patch in the center of the cap…” The volval patch on these obs is rather large, persistent and not easily removed except in the case of the old faded specimen. The gills on these obs appear fimbriate and are orange cream in color. And these obs were in association with ponderosa pine and gambel oak, in the case of 249154 pure ponderosa pine, at about 7300-7500’ elevation. I’m not sure about the habitat for A. nishidae though I know it was montane in the case of the southern Az collections and likely included one or more varieties of pine.

The second collection (see Observation 230596) of this beautiful and as of yet unidentified agaric. The pilei seen here are much browner, possibly due to age and/or or drier environmental conditions. Under the scope we found a sterile gill edge full of thin-walled, more or less finger-like cheilocystidia, along with sparser, thick-walled, apically encrusted (?) pleurocystidia, some appearing dextrinoid. Images of and notes on the charismatic stipe hairs are conspicuously and disappointingly absent. Long suspected of belonging to some xeruloid genus, we found the pileipellis to be a cutis, ruling out any such taxa with pileosetae (Xerula s. str. and Paraxerula). The hyaline spores are subglobose to broadly ellipsoid and somewhat angular, weakly amyloid (?), smooth, with a prominent hilar appendage and what appears to be a single, very large guttule taking up most of their interior.

The material should be reexamined on a higher quality microscope to confirm unclear features and record those which were un- or under-documented during the course.

results.notes: Dark reticulation, straight stem, some natural peeling (like Boletus edulis), pores stain brown immediately on contact. Cap is white or light grey. Firm flesh. Little flavor to taste, a pleasant mushroom smell.
Dark reddish-brown cap. Firm flesh, turns slightly brown when cut. Pleasat mushroom taste and smell. Brown staining on pores. Dark reticulation on stem.
Found on well rotting wood, likely hardwood.

Dr. Priscila Chaverri and her teaching assistant, Efraín Escudero-Leyva of the Instituto Politécnico Nacional in Mexico, were the course’s resident ascomycetologists. As this initially resembled one of the green Hypocrea/Trichoderma spp., I passed it on to them. After some microscopy and reference checking, Efraín returned with the provisional ID of Dactylospora, a (mostly) lichenicolous genus in the Lecanorales.

This is one of the most beautiful fungi I have ever seen, and I greatly look forward to discovering the rest of its name.

UPDATE 8/28/16: Believed to be a member of the genus Abrothallus by multiple members of the “Ascomycetes of the World” Facebook group. Name updated accordingly.

Biotopes : pousse au sol, au travers des copeaux de bois;
Genre Psathyrella;

Chapeau conique-campanulé, mamelonné, glabre, crème, grisâtre avec des teintes rosâtres, hygrophane, 6-40 mm Ø;
Pied cylindrique et parfois légèrement flexueux vers la base, beige pâle, cotonneux blanchâtre par endroit, semble avoir un petit bulbe à la base, dont le mycélium basale est attaché fermement au substrat, 10-81 × 1-5 mm Ø;
Lames veinées, beige, jaunes à noirâtres à maturité;
Voile partiel absent;
Odeur fongique;
Saveur fongique, douce;
Sporée noir à brun-pourpré foncé;

Micro
Planche micrographique : cKc0404-0099

Basides claviformes, tétrastérigmates, bouclées à la base, à contenu granuleux, 27 [30; 34] 36 × 11 [12; 13,5] 14 µm;
Spores elliptiques vue de front, elliptiques à oblongues allongées vue de profil, tronquées, lisses, à paroi mince à légèrement épaissie, avec petit appendice hilaire, pore germinatif central distinct entre 2,0-2,5 µm Ø, à contenu homogène [majoritairement uniguttulé à biguttulé, à variable avec technique à chaud dans le NH4OH 2 ], brun à brun foncé dans le NaCl iso, brun rougeâtre dans le Melzer, gris pourpre dans l’acide sulfurique 80 %, gris noirâtre dans le KOH 5 %, non cyanophiles

Cheilocystides abondantes, versiformes, difformes, sublagéniformes à lagéniformes avec parfois un col légèrement flexueux, rarement fusiformes, 26,4 [42,2; 58] 60,8 × 10 [13,9; 17,8] 21,7 µm;
Pleurocystides occasionnelles, lagéniformes, 45,6 [51,6; 63,5] 69,4 × 14,6 [16,1; 19,1] 20,6 µm;
Caulocystides peu abondantes, surtout en amas, souvent difformes à sublagéniformes 35,4 × 10,4 µm en moyenne, subfusiformes 26,3 [26,4; 27] 27,1 × 8,2 [8,5; 10,3] 10,7 µm;
Pileipellis formé de 2 à 3 couches de cellules vésiculeuses;

results.notes:
Lycoperdon pyriforme Schaeff. Lycoperdaceae, Lycoperdales. (Pear-shaped Puffball or Дождевик грушевидый.)
Mushroom: 1.5-4cm wide, 2-5 cm high, pear-shaped with elongated base as a false stalk; whitish and often with weak cream coloring (or very light coffee with milk); turban-shaped top with a stalk covered with tiny short brown or brownish spines and pyramids (when adult), at first it covered with irregular shape granules as a coarse brownish or white powder; cap and stalk compose a single body; young flesh is white, then greenish-yellow up to greenish-brown spore powder as dry dust. A stalk basement has white strands. A small 3-5mm hole appears at the top finally.
Habitat: crowded big or small clusters on old partially rotten wood in pine-tree forest with birches.
Edibility: edible and delicious when young and flesh is white.
Season: June-August.
